label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, April 12, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, addressing a rumor she had heard about his poor behavior at a party and explaining at whose houses he has dined.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, addressing a rumor she had heard about his poor behavior at a party and explaining at whose houses he has dined.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
April 12, 1943
Dear Gertie ,
Two no. 15s, one of April 3, and one of April 5 and then another
in a latter mail of today , which was still ahother 15 arrived today.
The letter telling me about the rumoir that I was at the Dillinghams
drunk and disorderly and was reprimanded by an Admiral made me so mad at
first that I dam near died. However I soon cooled down and had a good
laugh. First I do not know the Dillinghams, second I have never been hee for d-
dinner, thirdly I do not know an Admiral so have not bee[N] reprimanded.
You can rest assured that the person who told you the story is a bed liner
because an Admiral would~not think of bothering to reprimand you about
auythirg. It is the duty of the commanding officer to do this. The
Admiral would write him a letter asking that action be taken and the officer
would rite the admiral that action had been taken and discribing it.
I know all about these things because I exp administrativeo officer.
It is really amazing how stories start wi out any foundation at all.
I em so glad you wrote this to me so that I could at least tell :ttxho you
that it had never happened. Of course hundreds of people will hear the story
- embellish on it and retell this espisode until they will lmve he raping
the old lady on a card table while lorris stood by with a bottle in his hand
staggering drunkenly as he burped softly. However let me know the name ad
address of the person who told it to you so hat I can tell the SOB what I
think and that I intend to knock his face off when I return.
As I have told you in so mam' letters I have been to the
following three dinner . 1] The old Colonel ard his wife that knew Olive
Legendre. 2] Her daughter's house, Mrs Moody, 3] Mrs Wilders. Mrs Wilders
was the place I went last Saturday night and left so early. I never drakk
at any of these dinners nor was I rude. In fact I poured the butter on
so thick that you could not cut it with a knife. I don't drink because
I am afraid that I night say someth-ing that was secret, and I don't go out
unless I am caught in e trap. At the last dinner an old hag asked me
if I would come to dinn_er on Monday. I said no and said no to the next four
days. I agreed to come on Friday and will call her up Thursday and
say I am on night duty. They are a pain in the neck. I bet some old 
witch who had it in for Mrs Dillingham made up the story to get a kick in at
her with never a thought of how it would affect me. Anyway to hell with it.
I am as busy as a bird dog seeing that things are packed into -cases
and that everything is marked with the heme of the room and the officer or man
using it. At the end I am certain that no one will find anything but it will
not affect their work because they probably would not recognize it anyway. 
Will write you again after we move and tell you all the funny things that
happened. 
love to you darling
Sidney
